title: Thornbury sexual assault: Woman walking dog attacked at Mayer Park
text:
A woman walking a dog has been sexually assaulted in a Melbourne park but her act of bravery may have saved her life.

A woman’s act of bravery potentially saved her life on Saturday night after she was attacked by a sexual predator in a Melbourne park.

The 32-year-old woman was walking a friend’s dog alone about 10.30pm in Thornbury, north of Melbourne, when she noticed a man acting suspiciously on the footpath ahead.

To avoid him, she crossed to the other side of the road and then into Mayer Park — an expansive green space where she thought she would be safe.

He followed her and asked her if she could help him find something he had lost before producing a knife, forcing her to the ground and sexually assaulting her.

In the ensuing struggle, the woman grabbed the offender’s knife and stabbed him with it before running towards a motorist stopped at a red light adjacent to the park.

The sex attacker’s blood is still on the footpath near Mayer Park where he fled. Police say he likely sustained a serious puncture wound and will have required medical treatment for it.

The attack is a chilling reminder of what happened to Aiia Maasarwe and Eurydice Dixon who were also attacked and sexually assaulted while walking alone in Melbourne.

Both women were murdered at the hands of men.

Detective Acting Inspector Janet Mitchell said the attacker was “on a mission” when he attacked the 32-year-old.

She said police are looking for a man in her early 20s who is caucasian and has light brown hair. He was wearing a hoodie and loose-fitting pants.

“It could’ve ended up much worse. I think the woman was very brave to act the way she did,” Det Insp Mitchell said.

“She obviously made an assessment and made a decision on how she would handle it and it turned out very well for her.

“I think it’s quite frightening. I think he was on a mission. He saw the woman coming and he pursued her. When he could see that she was trying to get away, he tried to divert her attention, appealing to her good nature. He was able to grab her at that point.”

Investigators have doorknocked the area extensively and are asking anybody who was in the area to contact police.

Crime Stoppers: 1800 333 000 or www.crimestoppersvic.com.au.
description: A woman’s act of bravery potentially saved her life on Saturday night after she was attacked by a sexual predator in a Melbourne park.
